events.title: De Thiende
events.author: Simon Stevin
details: The book introduced the decimal fraction's notation.
It extended the principles of Hindu-Arabic arithmetic to calculation.

In the book, Stevin emphasized the utility of decimal arithmetic "for all accounts encountered in the affairs of men" and explained in an appendix how it could be applied to surveying, stereometry, astronomy, and mensuration.
Stevin showed how the usual arithmetic of whole numbers could be extended to decimal fractions using rules that determined the positioning of the negative powers of 10 (1.2 ⇒ 2 is 10^-1…).

Stevin's proposal required a rejection of the distinction in Euclidean geometry between magnitude, which is continuous, and number, which is a multitude of indivisible units. Decimal fractions seemed to imply that the unit could be subdivided and that arbitrary continuous magnitude could be represented numerically.

events.title: La Disme
events.author: Simon Stevin
details: A French version of “De Thiende”
Published by the original author, in the same printing shop and the same year as the Dutch version.

events.title: Perspective
events.author: Hans Vredeman de Vries
details: The text was issued simultaneously in French, Latin, Dutch and German in 1604-1605.
One of the major guidebooks on perspective for designers, painters, and architects.
sources: Kemp, M. (1986). Simon Stevin and Pieter Saenredam: A Study of Mathematics and Vision in Dutch Science and Art. The Art Bulletin, 68(2), 237–252. https://doi.org/10.2307/3050934

events.title: Opticae thesaurus
events.author: Friedrich Risner
details: First printed edition of Alhazen's Book of Optics that was available before in Latin as a manuscript.
As opposed to Euclid's Optics, this book argues that vision is a result og light rays entering the eye, and not emitted bt it.
The book was influential.
sources: Kemp, M. (1986). Simon Stevin and Pieter Saenredam: A Study of Mathematics and Vision in Dutch Science and Art. The Art Bulletin, 68(2), 237–252. https://doi.org/10.2307/3050934

events.title: L’Arithmetique
events.author: Simon Stevin
details: Stevin reiterates his theory of decimal fractions, provides a unifying theory for quadratic equations, and introduces a method of approximation to find the roots of higher order equations.

Criticizes the old distinction between numbers and magnitudes (grandeur), stating that number essentially belongs in the nature of magnitude. Argues that no number is discontinuous or discrete because numbers are measures, and all measures are continuous necessarily.
Argues that roots are numbers.
sources: Renaissance notions of number and magnitude. (2006). Historia Mathematica, 33(1), 63–81. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.hm.2004.11.011

events.title: De triangulis omnimodis
events.author: Regiomontanus
details: Deals with plane and spherical trigonometry.
Structured in a similar way to the Elements
States in the introduction that the science of triangles is necessary for astronomy.

events.title: Johnson’s “Arithmetic”
events.author: John Johnson
details: Used decimal fractions.

events.title: Cocker's Arithmetick
events.author: Edward Cocker
details: A famous “Arithmetic”.
Ignored decimal fractions.
Grammar school mathematics textbook.

events.title: Denniss (2006): Decimal fractions gain importance
details: According to Denniss (2006), decimal fractions held major significance only from the 18th century onwards

A possible reason, as suggested by Denniss (2006), is that in practical usage, they could often be circumvented by selecting a small base unit. Denniss (2006) asserts that even though decimal fractions were introduced as early as 1585, they experienced a slow adoption rate.

events.title: Mirifici Logarithmorum Canonis Descriptio
events.author: John Napier
details: The first published table of logarithms.
sources: Archibald, R. C. (1949). History of Mathematics After the Sixteenth Century. The American Mathematical Monthly, 56(1), 35–56. https://doi.org/10.2307/2304570

events.title: Briggs met Napier
details: Briggs met Napier in Edinburgh.
Briggs discussed with Nappier his suggestion of base 10 logarithms
It is possible that the first meeting was in 1615.

events.title: Briggs met Napier again
details: Briggs met Napier in Edinburgh for the second time.
Briggs discussed with Nappier his suggestion of base 10 logarithms.
It is possible that this meeting was in 1616.

events.title: Logarithmorum Chilias Prima
events.author: Henry Briggs
details: Includes tables of the logarithms from 1 to 1000, to 14 decimal places
A small booklet of 16 pages, privately printed, of which the first page was an introduction, and the remaining 15 pages were tables.

events.title: Mirifici logarithmorum canonis constructio
events.author: John Napier
details: Published posthumously by Napier's son.
Explains the principles used in the construction of his tables.

He presented a kinematic model where one particle's speed decreases proportionally to its remaining distance to a fixed point, forming a geometrically decreasing sequence, while another moves at a constant speed, forming an arithmetically increasing sequence. He used this model to derive theorems for approximating values in both sequences.

events.title: Arithmetische und Geometrische Progreß Tabulen
events.author: Jost Bürgi
details: Jost Bürgi was a clock and instrument maker at the court
This table, which appeared a short time after Napier’s table of logarithms, has often been viewed by historians of mathematics as an independent invention (or discovery) of logarithms.

events.title: Arithmetica Logarithmica
events.author: Henry Briggs
details: Advertised the utility of logarithms in expediting calculations.
Expound a number of methods to compute decimal logarithms.
Includes tables of logarithms from 1 to 20,000 and from 90,000 to 100,000 calculated to 14 decimal places.
sources: Archibald, R. C. (1949). History of Mathematics After the Sixteenth Century. The American Mathematical Monthly, 56(1), 35–56. https://doi.org/10.2307/2304570

events.title: Tabulae Rudolphinae
events.author: Johannes Kepler
details: Star catalogue and planetary table.
Based on Tycho Brahe's observations.
Includes logarithmic tables.

events.title: Trigonometria Britannica
events.author: Henry Briggs
details: Discuss the application of logarithms to trigonometric functions.
Appeared posthumously.

events.title: Behende und hupsche Rechnung auf allen kauffmanschafft
events.author: Johann Widmann
details: The first book to use the + and - signs.
Includes many examples for aiding "allen kauffmanschafft".

events.title: Summa de arithmetica, geometria, proportioni et proportionalita
events.author: Luca Pacioli
details: Textbook and reference work.
Includes the first printed example of a set of plus and minus signs: p̄ for "plus" and m̄ for "minus".

events.title: The Whetstone of Witte
events.author: Robert Recorde
details: The first book to use the = sign.

events.title: In artem analyticam isagoge
events.author: François Viète
details: Introduced letters to represent unknowns.
Used capital vowels for the unknowns and capital consonants for known quantities.

events.title: Methodus ad disquirendam maximam et minimam et de tangentibus linearum curvarum
events.author: Pierre de Fermat
details: Introduces a method of finding maxima, minima, and tangents to various curves.
Adopted Viète’s notation.
Considered an equation among two variables.
Showed that, if the equation is a quadratic, then the curve is a conic section.

events.title: La Géométrie
events.author: René Descartes
details: Published in 1637 as an appendix to his famous Discourse on Method.

Includes new notation: variables are represented by letters at the end of the alphabet, and known quantities by letters at the beginning of the alphabet. Includes exponential notation to indicate powers.
Do not adhere to the principle of homogeneity, which states that all terms in an equation must have the same dimension.
Shows by construction how to represent multiplication and divisions of lines.
Attempts to find the construction of solutions to geometric problems by means of instruments that were acceptable generalizations of ruler and compass.
Emphasize construction

Presents a method for determination of tangents that could in principle be applied to all curves that can be described by polynomial equations in two variables. This method relied on finding the normal line (a line perpendicular to the tangent) to the curve by using a condition: it should be the unique radius intersecting the curve at only one point.

events.title: Van Schooten Junior was first introduced to Descartes
details: Van Schooten was first introduced to Descartes through Golius.

events.title: Van Schooten Junior met Descartes
details: Van Schooten met Descartes through.
This was before the publication of La Géométrie.
Descartes asked van Schooten Junior to assist with making the illustrations.

events.title: Recueil de calcul pour l'intelligence de la Geometrie de Monsr des Cartes
events.author: Frans van Schooten
details: The title can be translated to: "Compendium of calculation for the understanding of the geometry of Descartes"

events.title: Van Schooten Junior met Mersenne
details: In Paris, Van Schooten learnt about the mathematical advances made by Viète and Fermat as well as having the opportunity to further his studies of Descartes' works.

events.title: Latin translation of La Géométrie
events.author: Frans van Schooten
details: Translation of La Géométrie into Latin.

events.title: Extended latin translation of La Géométrie
events.author: Frans van Schooten
details: Published between 1559-1661.
Includes an appendix by Johan Hudde that simplifies Descartes' method for finding tangents to curves.
According to the attached Britannica source, Newton was influenced by this work.

events.title: Geometria Indivisibilibus Continuorum
events.author: Bonaventura Cavalieri
details:
Formulates a systematic method for the determination of areas and volumes.
Regarded plane figure as being composed of a collection of indivisible lines.
These collections could be interpreted as magnitudes obeying the rules of Euclidean ratio theory.
In his system, deriving simple results required intricate geometric considerations.
Written in a turgid style

events.title: Arithmetica Infinitorum
events.author: John Wallis
details: Expresses the area under a curve as the sum of an infinite series and used unrigorous inductions to determine its value.
According to the atached Britannica source, Newton was influenced by this work.

events.title: Discorsi e dimostrazioni matematiche intorno a due nuove scienze
events.author: Galileo Galilei
details: Discusses the motion of projectiles that consist of two components: a constant horizontal component and a vertical component that varies with time. The combination produces a parabolic curve.

events.title: Opera Geometrica
events.author: Evangelista Torricelli
details: Discusses the cycloid, a curve traced by a point on the circumference of a circle as the circle rolls along a straight line.

According to Gliozzi (1972), the work, was known throughout Italy and Europe and had intrinsic value. Through its clear exposition it diffused the geometry of Cavalieri, whose writings were difficult to read.
sources: Gliozzi, Mario. “Torricelli, Evangelista.” In Dictionary of Scientific Biography, edited by C. C. Gillespie, xiii:433–440. New York: Scribner, 1972.
Wolfson, P. R. (2001). The Crooked Made Straight: Roberval and Newton on Tangents. The American Mathematical Monthly, 108(3), 206–216. https://doi.org/10.2307/2695381

events.title: A letter from Torricelli to Roberval
details: Toricelli gets in touch with Roberval and reports to him about his views and results on the centre of gravity of the parabola, the semigeneral paraboles, the surface of the cycloid and its history, the solid of revolution generated by a conic and the hyperbolic acute solid.

events.title: Torricelli gathers his correspondence with Roberval
details: Roberval accused Torricelli of plagiarism.
According to the attached sources, nowadays historians largely believe they got to the results independently.

events.title: Lectiones Geometricae
events.author: Isaac Barrow
details: Show that the determinations of areas and tangents are inverse problems.
Borrow's work, and particularly his Lectiones Geometricae, are highly regarded by historians of calculus.

events.title: Newton finished his work on "De Methodis Serierum et Fluxionum"
events.author: Isaac Newton
details: A seminal work that introduced many of the foundational concepts and methods of calculus.
Formalized methods for finding tangents and areas under curves
His rules and notations provided a framework that could be broadly applied to various problems, not just specific geometric cases.
Used ideas from kinematics: a variable was a "fluent", it's rate of change was a "fluxion".
Notation: a dot above a variable indicated a fluxion.

events.title: Leibniz met Huygens and studied under him
details: Huygens tutored Leibniz until 1676 and they kept corresponding.

events.title: Nova Methodus pro Maximis et Minimis
events.author: Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz

events.title: De Methodis Serierum et Fluxionum
events.author: Isaac Newton
details: Newton's work was published, 65 years after it was written.

events.title: Advancement of Learning
events.author: Francis Bacon
details: Proposes to strengthen the emphasis on philosophy and natural knowledge to address defects crippling contemporary education.
Propose creating university positions devoted to artes and sciences at large, rather than to specific profession.
Argues that the teaching of sciences should involve technical education. Suggests to use instruments and experiments.
sources: Popper, N. (2006). “Abraham, Planter of Mathematics”: Histories of Mathematics and Astrology in Early Modern Europe. Journal of the History of Ideas, 67(1), 87–106.

events.title: Pico planned a public disputation of his 900 theses
details: Pico argued that all philosophical and theological schools, including the Christianity, Kabbalah, Islam, etc., originated from the same source, and exemplify the same truth.
Exemplifies the Renaissance interest in the unity of knowledge and synthesis of different traditions.
The disputation was cancelled by Pope Innocent VIII.

events.title: Pico composed Oratio de hominis dignitate
events.author: Giovanni Pico della Mirandola
details: Revers freedom and capacity to know and to dominate reality.
Considered the "Manifesto of the Renaissance."

events.title: Ramus was banned from teaching philosophy
details: According to Goulding (2006), Ramus's attacks on Aristotle and modern logic provoked his politically influential opponents, and he was banned by the royal order.
Goulding (2006) claim that the ban caused Ramus to focus on mathematics.
sources: Goulding, R. (2006). Method and Mathematics: Peter Ramus’s Histories of the Sciences. Journal of the History of Ideas, 67(1), 63–85.

events.Title: St. Bartholomew's Day massacre
details: French Catholics targeted and killed thousands of Huguenots, French Protestants, in Paris and other parts of France.
Peter Ramus was killed in the massacre.

events.title: Oratio de studiis mathematiciis
events.author: Petrus Ramus
details: Few pages long oratio, part of a book that includes 3 other orations.
Expresses the highest appreciation for mathematics, as it was used by Archimedes for practice and by Plato for contemplation.
sources: Strazzoni, A. (2017). Ramism. In M. Sgarbi (Ed.), Encyclopedia of Renaissance Philosophy (pp. 1–16). Springer International Publishing. https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-319-02848-4_683-1

events.title: Arithmetica
events.author: Petrus Ramus
details: Ramus changes his previously attitude towards mathematics, no longer viewing it as the most natual and well organized art.

Argues that Euclid violated two of his laws of method: he broke the law of justice/homogeneity by mixing geometry and arithmetic, and the law of wisdom by starting  with geometry, whereas the treatment of quantity (in arithmetic) has to come first.
Calls for reorganization of mathematics, which will make the demonstration, which he viewed as mere explanations, unnecessary, because the reorganization will make the truth evident.
sources: Strazzoni, A. (2017). Ramism. In M. Sgarbi (Ed.), Encyclopedia of Renaissance Philosophy (pp. 1–16). Springer International Publishing. https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-319-02848-4_683-1
Goulding, R. (2006). Method and Mathematics: Peter Ramus’s Histories of the Sciences. Journal of the History of Ideas, 67(1), 63–85.

events.title: Scholae mathematicae
events.author: Petrus Ramus
details: Criticizes Plato for making mathematics too abstract and compares him to the selfish Christian theologian who usurped the study of God from the common people.
Criticizes ancient mathematics for not applying mathematics to practical disciplines.
Includes an extended history of mathematics, starting with the first man - Adam.
Links Germany's success in mining and fortification (and the wealth of its princes) with it's mathematical education.
sources: Strazzoni, A. (2017). Ramism. In M. Sgarbi (Ed.), Encyclopedia of Renaissance Philosophy (pp. 1–16). Springer International Publishing. https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-319-02848-4_683-1
Goulding, R. (2006). Method and Mathematics: Peter Ramus’s Histories of the Sciences. Journal of the History of Ideas, 67(1), 63–85.
Popper, N. (2006). “Abraham, Planter of Mathematics”: Histories of Mathematics and Astrology in Early Modern Europe. Journal of the History of Ideas, 67(1), 87–106.
Keller, A. (1985). Mathematics, Mechanics and the Origins of the Culture of Mechanical Invention. Minerva, 23(3), 348–361.

events.title: Pathwaie to Knowledge
events.author: Robert Recorde
details: No proofs are given in this book. Instead, Recorde explains why the theorems are true and gives examples to aid a student to understand not only what was being taught, but why it was being taught.
From the preface: "Carpenters, Karvers, Joyners and masons doo willingly acknowledge that they can worke nothyng without reason of geometrie"
States that the necessary instruments for many practices, like sailing the sea, are founded by geometers.

events.title: Arithmetica e geometria
events.author: Giovanni Francesco Peverone
details: Includes surveying techniques as part of the discussion of geometry.

events.title: Protomathesis
events.author: Oronce Fine
details: Compendium of mathematics consisting of writings on arithmetic, geometry, trigonometry, astronomy, and instrument-making.
Includes examples of the use of mathematics in practical applications, such as the use of a quadrant in determining the inaccessible depth of a well.
Quote (translated by Keller, 1985): "you will not be able to understand the proper causes of things unless you establish the numbers, and are at the same time a geometer".

events.title: Cannons became a decisive instrument of war
details: According to Keller (1985), around 1500 cannons has reached sufficient efficiency and mobility to become a decisive instrument of war.
According to Keller (1985), this led to a change in the old war style, development of fortifications and the need for mathematical knowledge to design them.
sources: Keller, A. (1985). Mathematics, Mechanics and the Origins of the Culture of Mechanical Invention. Minerva, 23(3), 348–361.

events.title: Libellus de Locorum describendorum ratione
events.author: Gemma Frisius
details: Suggested the use of triangulation for map making.
This is a pamphlet that was presented as the Appendix to the 1533 edition of the Cosmographica of Peter Apian.
sources: Keller, A. (1985). Mathematics, Mechanics and the Origins of the Culture of Mechanical Invention. Minerva, 23(3), 348–361.

events.title: Theatrum Instrumentorum
events.author: Jacques Besson
details: Includes designs of multiple inventions and instruments.
The book was published in a rash, possibly due to the political situation that forced Basson to leave France.
The book became very popular and inspired imitators like Jean Errard and Agostino Ramelli.
Keller (1985, 1965) views this publication as a milestone in the "theatre of machines" genre.
sources: Keller, A. (1985). Mathematics, Mechanics and the Origins of the Culture of Mechanical Invention. Minerva, 23(3), 348–361.
Keller, A. (1965). Introduction. In A theatre of machines. New York, Macmillan. http://archive.org/details/theatreofmachine01kell

events.title: Theatrum Instrumentorum (2nd edition)
events.author: Jacques Besson
details: A decorated and illustrated edition, printed posthumously with added content by François Béroalde de Verville.
sources: Keller, A. (1965). Introduction. In A theatre of machines. New York, Macmillan. http://archive.org/details/theatreofmachine01kell

events.title: Premier Livre des instruments mathématiques et mécaniques
events.author: Jean Errard
details: An early book of Errard, inspired by Besson's Theatrum Instrumentorum.
sources: Keller, A. (1985). Mathematics, Mechanics and the Origins of the Culture of Mechanical Invention. Minerva, 23(3), 348–361.

events.title: La fortification démonstrée et réduicte en art
events.author: Jean Errard
details: The most famous book of Errard, which was translated to multiple languages and had a few editions.

events.title: Le diverse et artificiose machine
events.author: Agostino Ramelli
details: Inspired by Besson's Theatrum Instrumentorum (Keller, 1985).

Offers original designs of "mechanical" solutions to practical problems, like water management, grain milling, excavation, hauling of heavy objects, siege and defense of cities, and even the entertainment.
Includes many illustrations, accompanied by detailed descriptions in French and Italian.
sources: Keller, A. (1985). Mathematics, Mechanics and the Origins of the Culture of Mechanical Invention. Minerva, 23(3), 348–361.

events.title: De Re Metallica
events.author: Georgius Agricola
details: A book about mining that includes a detailed description of the machines used in mining.
The book was very popular throughout Europe (Keller, 1985).
sources: Keller, A. (1985). Mathematics, Mechanics and the Origins of the Culture of Mechanical Invention. Minerva, 23(3), 348–361.
